evidence.text: In October 2023, Plaintiff Erie County, New York, applied for a grant from Defendant Corporation for National and Community Service (“Americorps”).

extracted.value: Erie County applied for a grant in October 2023.

evidence.text: In January 2024, Americorps approved the grant.

extracted.value: Americorps approved the grant in January 2024.

evidence.text: On October 2023, Erie County applied for a three-year RSVP grant for a total award of approximately $250,000.

extracted.value: Grant term is three years with an award of approximately $250,000.

evidence.text: On February 14, 2025, Americorps sent Erie County a letter explaining that “Americorps is continuing to review all applicable executive orders, memoranda, and corresponding guidance issued since January 20, 2025, by President Trump … Americorps is taking proactive action to ensure alignment with these directives and the Trump‑Vance administration priorities.”

The letter gave Erie County three options: It could “reply all to this letter by email by February 19, 2025” and “copy and paste this statement … ‘I certify that RSVP of Erie County … complies with all administration Executive Orders and does not include any activities that promote DEI activities.’”

extracted.value: Americorps sent a letter on February 14, 2025 threatening termination unless a self‑certification is provided.

evidence.text: "I certify that RSVP of Erie County … complies with all administration Executive Orders and does not include any activities that promote DEI activities."

extracted.value: The letter required Erie County to provide a self‑certification statement: "I certify that RSVP of Erie County … complies with all administration Executive Orders and does not include any activities that promote DEI activities."

evidence.text: On February 20, 2025, Erie County responded to Americorps, writing: “Erie County proudly supports the Americorps Retired Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP) grant. RSVP staff are performing duties in line with Americorps guidelines. Our 450 volunteers have provided 37,000 hours of service to our community through partnership with 60 local organizations.”

extracted.value: Erie County responded on February 20, 2025 with a statement supporting the program and its volunteer impact.

evidence.text: On February 24, 2025, Erie County’s attorney emailed a copy of a temporary injunction … Americorps said that although “in accordance with the preliminary injunction, [it] will not take any action related to award terminations …” it nonetheless demanded that Erie County “please continue with your review … including submitting the self‑certification or amendment, as applicable.”

extracted.value: Americorps responded on February 24, 2025 acknowledging the preliminary injunction and stating it would not take action related to award terminations, but also demanding that Erie County continue the review and submit the self‑certification.

evidence.text: On March 11, 2025, Americorps wrote to Erie County: “Thank you for your response … In accordance with the preliminary injunction, no additional action is needed at this time and you may continue with grant activities.”

extracted.value: Americorps wrote on March 11, 2025 that no additional action is needed at this time and Erie County may continue with grant activities.

evidence.text: On March 12, 2025, Americorps emailed Erie County to explain that further action was required to approve Erie County’s continuation of its grant. Americorps attached to its March 12 email the same guidance document referenced attached as Exhibit A.

extracted.value: Americorps wrote on March 12, 2025 requiring further action to approve Erie County’s continuation of its grant, attaching guidance as Exhibit A.

evidence.text: On January 20, 2025, the President signed Executive Order 14151, titled “Ending Radical Government DEI Programs and Preferencing.” The order ... required federal agencies to terminate ... all ... ‘equity‑related’ grants or contracts within sixty days.

extracted.value: Executive Order 14151 issued on January 20, 2025 required federal agencies to terminate equity‑related grants or contracts within sixty days.

evidence.text: Americorps’ threats violate the Administrative Procedures Act because they are arbitrary and capricious, and they violate the Constitution because they impose imprecise and unauthorized restrictions on federal funding to a local government.

extracted.value: Americorps claims that its actions violate the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution by imposing arbitrary and capricious restrictions on federal funding.

evidence.text: Americorps was founded in 1993 to promote volunteerism and national community service, but RSVP traces its origins to the Older Americans Act of 1969, in which Congress sought to promote the involvement of older Americans (then defined as 60 years or older) in addressing local problems.

By the late 1980’s, more than 400,000 senior volunteers were serving in approximately 750 RSVP projects across the country, and by the mid‑2000s into the present day RSVP programs have seen up to half a million volunteers working in a year in almost every state.

extracted.value: Background: Americorps was founded in 1993; RSVP program originates from the Older Americans Act of 1969 and has served over 400,000 senior volunteers nationwide.

evidence.text: RSVP does this through a wide range of volunteering activities, from delivering meals through the well‑known Meals on Wheels program, to promoting disaster preparedness and helping older Americans with their taxes.

extracted.value: RSVP program includes Meals on Wheels and other volunteer activities aimed at serving seniors.
